review.title: Reachability Under Uncertainty
review.abstract: firstly in this paper we introduce somewhat a new network reachability mathematical problem where the sole goal difference is to always find the logical most independently reliable path chosen between two connected nodes in crossing a network, represented as involving a directed acyclic partition graph. individual edges within this network may theoretically fail according to those certain optimal probabilities, and these failure probabilities may depend merely on not the finite values of probability one 100 or more hidden adjacent variables. formally this second problem may be viewed as a generalization of basic shortest - path problems for finding minimum discount cost paths globally or viterbi - type problems for finding highest - probability symmetric sequences of bound states, unless where the addition is of the hidden different variables, introduces correlations signals that are evidently not handled by previous algorithms. previously we give theoretical search results, characterizing this numerical problem including an approximately np - loss hardness proof. actually we also briefly give an exact sum algorithm and a more obviously efficient approximation method algorithm for this problem.
histories: Appears in Proceedings of the Twenty-Third Conference on Uncertainty in Artificial Intelligence (UAI2007)
review.COMMENTS: Appears in Proceedings of the Twenty-Third Conference on Uncertainty in Artificial Intelligence (UAI2007)

metadata.abstractText: In this paper we introduce a new network reachability problem where the goal is to find the most reliable path between two nodes in a network, represented as a directed acyclic graph. Individual edges within this network may fail according to certain probabilities, and these failure probabilities may depend on the values of one or more hidden variables. This problem may be viewed as a generalization of shortest-path problems for finding minimum cost paths or Viterbi-type problems for finding highest-probability sequences of states, where the addition of the hidden variables introduces correlations that are not handled by previous algorithms. We give theoretical results characterizing this problem including an NP-hardness proof. We also give an exact algorithm and a more efficient approximation algorithm for this problem.
metadata.creator: Adobe InDesign CS2 (4.0.4)
